title: How to Make a Daisy Centerpiece in a Coffee Can

steps.headline: Find your special flower.
steps.description: While the daisy works extremely well sitting inside this can, you can partner just about any type of flower. The combination of the metal steel can with the soft flirtiness of flowers will compliment any table setting. Determine if you want fresh or silk flowers. Today's silk flowers are extremely realistic and can pass for the real thing. Price out both to weight cost versus style benefits. Visit a reputable florist. If you plan to go with fresh flowers, be sure you are getting quality blooms. It's imperative that the flowers that are placed inside the can are hearty and fresh. Wilting flowers will detract from what you are trying to accomplish with this centerpiece.

steps.headline: Pick up coffee cans.
steps.description: No dented or compromised cans and be sure they all have a removable, paper label (or better yet--no label). Choose a uniform size but consider adding smaller, complimentary cans to dress your drink or guestbook table. Canned vegetables (as long as they have a paper label) will do the trick.

steps.headline: Pick up a  ball of twine, a floral knife and make sure you have a clean cloth and soap and water to help loosen the can label.
Trim and sustain flowers in water.
steps.description: If you've purchased your flowers have a staging area so they can stay fresh in water. Complete any trimming or pruning so all you will need to do is transfer the waiting flowers to prepared cans.

steps.headline: Remove can labels.
steps.description: Perform this step carefully as you will need to make sure you don't scratch or dent the cans. Scrub any remaining glue from the label that may still be on the can. Use mild soap and warm water to gently remove any leftover glue.

steps.headline: Open cans and discard contents.
steps.description: Don't throw away contents but instead find another receptacle or container for the goods/coffee. Also, if you are throwing a party, consider using the coffee or can contents in your meal plan.

steps.headline: Clean cans thoroughly with soap and water.
steps.description: Don't soak or allow the cans to linger in the water as they could rust. Dry with a clean towel and set aside.

steps.headline: Cut a long strand of twine that can be used to wrap around the outside of the can.
steps.description: You may want to either measure or simply cut an extra long strand.

steps.headline: Wrap the twine around the can and then tie with a simple bow.
steps.description: Center the bow in the middle of the can.

steps.headline: Fill cans halfway with water if filling them with fresh flowers.
steps.description: Add a dash of 7-Up to extend the flower's life.

steps.headline: Add bunches of flowers to each can.
steps.description: Arrange and position flowers once they've made it to their “final destination” (the table).

text: Pick up Flowers and Supplies Find your special flower. While the daisy works extremely well sitting inside this can, you can partner just about any type of flower. The combination of the metal steel can with the soft flirtiness of flowers will compliment any table setting. Determine if you want fresh or silk flowers. Today's silk flowers are extremely realistic and can pass for the real thing. Price out both to weight cost versus style benefits. Visit a reputable florist. If you plan to go with fresh flowers, be sure you are getting quality blooms. It's imperative that the flowers that are placed inside the can are hearty and fresh. Wilting flowers will detract from what you are trying to accomplish with this centerpiece. Pick up coffee cans. No dented or compromised cans and be sure they all have a removable, paper label (or better yet--no label). Choose a uniform size but consider adding smaller, complimentary cans to dress your drink or guestbook table. Canned vegetables (as long as they have a paper label) will do the trick. Pick up a  ball of twine, a floral knife and make sure you have a clean cloth and soap and water to help loosen the can label.  Create Centerpieces Trim and sustain flowers in water. If you've purchased your flowers have a staging area so they can stay fresh in water. Complete any trimming or pruning so all you will need to do is transfer the waiting flowers to prepared cans. Remove can labels. Perform this step carefully as you will need to make sure you don't scratch or dent the cans. Scrub any remaining glue from the label that may still be on the can. Use mild soap and warm water to gently remove any leftover glue. Open cans and discard contents. Don't throw away contents but instead find another receptacle or container for the goods/coffee. Also, if you are throwing a party, consider using the coffee or can contents in your meal plan. Clean cans thoroughly with soap and water. Don't soak or allow the cans to linger in the water as they could rust. Dry with a clean towel and set aside. Cut a long strand of twine that can be used to wrap around the outside of the can. You may want to either measure or simply cut an extra long strand. Wrap the twine around the can and then tie with a simple bow. Center the bow in the middle of the can. Fill cans halfway with water if filling them with fresh flowers. Add a dash of 7-Up to extend the flower's life. Add bunches of flowers to each can. Arrange and position flowers once they've made it to their “final destination” (the table).
